question:
(a) Describe any four features of a multiple shop.

(b) Give any four reasons why small scale retailing is common in Nigeria.
answer:
(a) Features of a Multiple shop are:

(i) A multiple shop specialises in single commodity lines.

(ii) It has a central administration and control.

(iii) The numerous branches of a multiple shop system are usually spread over the country.

(iv) The numerous branches are owned by one single firm.

(v) The goods sold in all the branches are bought by the head office and sent to the branches.

(b) Small scale retailing is common in Nigeria for the following reasons:

(i) Lack of true entrepreneurship prevents many people from establishing large retail business units.

(ii) There is absence of developed market in West Africa.

(iii) Inadequate and inefficient means of transport and communication in West Africa do not create room for large retail trade but small ones.

(iv) Lack of sufficient capital on the part of businessmen that should be used in establishing large retail organisations.

(v) Small scale retailing requires small capital which many people can easily provide.

(vi) Low per capita income hence, majority can only afford to buy goods in units.

question:
(a) State any four sources of capital for a public limited company.

(b) Explain any four advantages and disadvantages respectively of converting a business into a public limited company.
answer:
(a) Sources of Capital for a public limited company are:

(i) Sale of shares to the public.

(ii) Bank loan and overdrafts.

(iii) Debentures.

(iv) Equipment leasing.

(v) Ploughing back of profit.

(vi) Hire purchases.

(vii) Bill of Exchange.

(b) Advantages of public limited company are:

(i) The business will become a legal entity: It can sue and be sued as a corporate body.

(ii) The company enjoys limited liability: The shareholder's liability is limited to the amount of shares held, or agreed to purchase.

(iii) The public limited company has ability to raise large capital by offering shares of various types to the public.

(iv) The public limited company has a continuous existence independent of its members. The death of even the largest shareholders does not affect its existence.

(v) The public limited company operates on a large scale and therefore enjoys the economies of large scale.

(vi) It can easily raise loans e.g debentures.

(vii) It has enough capital to engage specialists.

Disadvantages of converting a business into a public limited company are:

(I) The law requires several formalities to be performed before a limited liability company is created. These formalities cost quite a lot of money.

(ii) It is slower to make decisions in a limited company than in the case of a sole trading business. This is simply because more people are involved in decision making processes.

(iii) The management of the company are not the actual owners of the business.

(iv) There is very little privacy in its affairs as it is required to publish its account to the public.

(v) Unlike the case of the partnership, owners of a limited company do not have a personal touch with their business.

question:
Write short notes on the following, showing their main uses in foreign trade:

(a) Shipping notes

(b) Ship's manifest

(c) Bill of sight

(d) Dock warrant

(d) Bill of entry.
answer:
(a) Shipping Note; is a document sent by the exporter or his agent to the ports authorities when goods that are to be exported have been carried to the docks, giving detailed information about the goods. This document, also known as a formal request to the ports authorities is the docks superintendent, regarding shipment, disclosing the type of goods to be carried, its port of destination, the vessel that will carry the good etc. The exporter or his agent retains a copy of the shipping note.

(b) Ship's Manifest; is a document prepared and lodged with the custom's authorities by the captain of a ship, giving full particulars of the crew, passengers and cargoes carried as well as the destination of the ship. The ship's manifest must be lodged with the custom's authorities before the ship leaves the port where the goods were loaded. Like the customs specification, ship's manifest lodged by the captain of the ship also enables the customs authorities to prove the accuracy or other wise of the particulars, the exporters had already supplied.

(c) Bill of sight; is an important trade document used in import trade and usually given to the customs officer when a full description of the goods cannot be provided. This enables the goods to berth. However, a full description of the goods must be made later.

(d) Dock warrant; is also known as wharfinger's receipt or dock receipt. it states that the exporter has kept the goods at the warehouse awaiting loading. It can equally be the importer who kept the goods at the port's warehouse awaiting clearing.

(e) Bill of entry; is a foreign trade document containing the particulars of all goods imported into the country. It provides the customs authority with the particulars of goods imported at the port of entry.

question:
(a) Describe the functions of the Stock Exchange.

(b) State the types of securities traded in the Stock Exchange.
answer:
(a) Functions of the Stock Exchange are:

(i) The stock exchange helps companies to raise capital needed for their business operations.

(ii) The government can also raise capital through members of the public when it issues government bonds. These bonds are sold in the market.

(iii) The stock exchange provides professional advice on the selection and management of investments.

(iv) It makes it possible for investment to be converted into cash.

(v) An investor is able to transfer his shares to another person through the stock exchange.

(vi) Prices quoted on the stock Exchange Market serves as a yard stick with which to measure the good will of a company.

(vii) Prices of shares and securities are determined by the stock exchange based on the forces of demand and supply.

(viii) It is a market for buying and selling of securities.

(ix) The market assists a private company to go public without issuing new shares.

(x) It renders agency services by buying and selling securities on behalf of investors, firms, governments etc.

(b) Types of Securities traded in the stock exchange are:

(i) Stock
(ii) Shares
(iii) Debentures
(iv) Government stock i.e Gilt-edged securities.
(v) Bonds.

question:
(a) What are Thrift Societies?

(b) Describe five services rendered by Thrift Societies to their members.
answer:
(a) Thrift societies; are associations established to encourage savings among members . Members are made to contribute money at regular intervals (e.g monthly) out of which loans are granted to members who are in need of finance. It is formed by low income earners. Interests charged on loans are usually low as compared to that charged on bank loans.

(b) Services rendered by thrift societies to their members are:

(i) The thrift societies grant loans to members at low interest rates with no requirement for a collateral.

(ii) Members are encouraged to save a little of their income.

(iii) A member of a co-operative thrift society can obtain money to buy items which he would have otherwise been unable to afford.

(iv) The society can act as guarantors to their members who may involve in hire purchase.

(v) They encourage inter-personal relationship through the brotherly and friendly relationship that exist among their members.

question:
(a) Explain five problems of using rail transport in Nigeria.

(b) Write short notes on;
(i) Tramp liners
(ii) Ocean liners.
answer:
(a) Problems of rail transport in Nigeria are:

(I) The train may be slower on short routes.

(ii) The cost of running rail transport is enormous.

(iii) Rail transport is characterised by delays and so may be unsuitable where goods are needed to be delivered very fast.

(iv) Trains cannot deliver directly to the customer. It usually has to rely on road transport to deliver goods to the final destination goods to the final destinations.

(v) Trains cannot move into warehouses or factory premises to collect goods.

(b)(i) Tramp liners; have no defined route and do not run on schedule. They are used as cargo taxi cabs in water transport and are smaller in size than ocean liners. They can be used in carrying goods anywhere they are found.

(ii) Ocean liners; include passenger and cargo liners. Cargo liners are ships used in carrying goods along high seas and oceans. Cargo liners operate on schedule and they have specific routes. Passenger liners are ships used in carrying passengers on high seas and oceans. They operate on schedule and have specific routes also.

question:
(a) What is a contract of sale of goods?

(b) State any three of its provisions.

(c) Explain two conditions that constitute acceptance in the contract of sale of goods.
answer:
(a) Contract of sale of goods; is a contract whereby the seller transfers or agrees to transfer the property in goods to the buyer for a money consideration called the price.

(b)The provisions of contract of sale of goods include:

(i) The price in a contract of sale may be fixed by the contract or may be left to be fixed in a manner thereby agreed.

(ii) The seller has the right to sell the goods.

(iii) The goods sold must correspond with the description.

(iv) The goods sold must be reasonably fit for the purpose for which it is meant.

(v) There is an implied condition that the goods are of merchantable quality.

(vi) The bulk shall correspond with the sample in quality.

(c) Conditions that constitute acceptance in the contract of sale of goods are:

(i) If the buyer retains the goods without giving notice of rejection within a reasonable time.

(ii) When the buyer signifies his approval or acceptance to the seller.

(iii) He does something inconsistent with the title of the seller.

question:
(a). What is Public Relations?

(b) State and explain any five methods a firm can use to promote its public relations.
answer:
(a) Public Relations activities; are those activities, devices and strategies which the firm adopts in order to endear itself to the customers, win public acceptance and acquire some goodwill. It is defined by the British Institute of Public Relations as " a planned and sustained effort to establish and maintain mutual understanding between an organization and the public".

(b) Five methods which a firm can use to promote its Public Relations are:
(i) Trade fairs
(ii) Exhibitions
(iii) Features Articles
(iv) Gift and free samples
(v) Sponsored programmes
(vi) Seminars I conferences

(i) Trade fairs: Through trade fairs, producers and distributors of goods and services display their products to members of the public. All firms use the opportunity to build a good public image and to become popular. Some reputable trade fairs have been held in Kano, Lagos and Kaduna.

(ii) Exhibitions: An exhibition is a public organised display of goods by firms in the same industry or firms from different industry aimed at promoting trade.

(iii) Feature articles: These consist of literature and publications about a firm's products and activities.

(iv) Gifts I free samples: Public relation activities can take the form of gifts distributed to members of the public. The gifts can include biro, pens etc.

(v) Sponsored programmes: A company can sponsor programmes to boost its image.

(vi) Seminars I Conferences: Seminars can be organised to boost the image of a company.

question: Mention and explain any four environments under which a business operates.
answer:
Environments under which a business operates are:

(i) Technological environment: Technological changes make previous material obsolete, hence businesses adjust to changes in technology.

(ii) Legal environment: The business has to operate bearing in mind that the legal provisions such as decrees, rules and regulations that affect its operations are to be obeyed.

(iii) Social environment: Changes in the social environment affect consumers' attitude and life style which invariably affect their purchasing and consumption habit .

(iv) Physical/Climatic environment: Changes such as desert encroachment, drought, erosion, river pollution and depletion have effects on business organisations.

(v) Cultural environment: Culture has a bearing on consumption pattern. The type of goods to purchase and the values held by consumers are determined by culture. Some do not take alcohol while others do.

(vi) Political environment: Government policies determine business practices and investment climates in an economy. The priority of the political party in power would definitely affect business operations negatively or positively.

question:
(a).Give five examples of trade associations.

(b) Outline any three functions of the Employers' Association.

(c) What are the objectives of the Lake Chad Basin Commission?
answer:
(a) Examples of trade associations are:

(i) Manufacturers Association of Nigeria.

(ii) Taxi Drivers' Association.

(iii) Garri Sellers Association.

(iv) Cement Dealers Association.

(v) Nigerian Union of Teachers.

(b) Function of Employers Association are:

(i) It collaborates with trade unions in settling disputes between employers and employees.

(ii) It also ensures health and welfare of workers.

(iii) It establishes satisfactory terms and conditions of employment.

(iv) It provides standards of safety for workers.

(v) It maintains standard and ensures that terms and conditions in the contract of employment are obeyed by the employers and employees.

(c) Objectives of Lake Chad Basin Commission are:

(i) To resettle the persons affected by the works and schemes stated under special resettlement schemes.

(ii) To enhance the agricultural potentials of Lake Chad Basin area for irrigation.

(iii) To undertake projects for control of flood and erosion.

(iv) To construct and maintain dams, wells, boreholes, drainages, irrigation systems.

(v) To control pollution of rivers and Lakes.

(vi) To teach farmers modern farming methods.

(vii) To foster economic co-operation and development among member nations.
